title: Second Highest Salary
markdown:
# **Second Highest Salary**

## Write a SQL query to get the second highest salary from the Employee table. Return NULL if there is no second highest salary.

### Table Schema
| Column | Type    |
|--------|---------|
| id     | INTEGER |
| salary | INTEGER |

### Example

**Input:**
```
**Employee**
+----+--------+
| id | salary |
+----+--------+
| 1  | 100    |
| 2  | 200    |
| 3  | 300    |
+----+--------+
```

**Expected Output:**
```
+---------------------+
| SecondHighestSalary |
+---------------------+
| 200                 |
+---------------------+
```

testCases.setupSql: CREATE TABLE Employee(id INT, salary INT); INSERT INTO Employee VALUES (1,100),(2,200),(3,300);
testCases.solutionSql: SELECT MAX(salary) as SecondHighestSalary FROM Employee WHERE salary < (SELECT MAX(salary) FROM Employee);

testCases.setupSql: CREATE TABLE Employee(id INT, salary INT); INSERT INTO Employee VALUES (1,100);
testCases.solutionSql: SELECT MAX(salary) as SecondHighestSalary FROM Employee WHERE salary < (SELECT MAX(salary) FROM Employee);

testCases.setupSql: CREATE TABLE Employee(id INT, salary INT); INSERT INTO Employee VALUES (1,100),(2,100),(3,200);
testCases.solutionSql: SELECT MAX(salary) as SecondHighestSalary FROM Employee WHERE salary < (SELECT MAX(salary) FROM Employee);

testCases.setupSql: CREATE TABLE Employee(id INT, salary INT);
testCases.solutionSql: SELECT MAX(salary) as SecondHighestSalary FROM Employee WHERE salary < (SELECT MAX(salary) FROM Employee);
